D.text:
After three months Freshitt had become rather
oppressive: to sit like a model for Saint Catherine looking rapturously
at Celia's baby would not do for many hours in the day, and to remain
in that mome

in her quiet unemphatic way shot a needle-arrow of
sarcasm.

I shall often come here, and I shall see how baby grows all the
better,
Dear Kitty, I will come and stay all night on purpose,

but I want to be alone now, and in my own home.  I wish to know the
Farebrothers better, and to talk to Mr. Farebrother about what there is
to be done in Middlemarch.

I never called everything by the same name that all the people about
me did,
No,

I still think that the greater part of the world is mistaken
about many things.  Surely one may be sane and yet think so, since the
greater part of the world has often had to come round from its opini

I
could not use it.  Do you not see now that I could not submit my soul
to yours, by working hopelessly at what I have no belief in—Dorothea?

The longing was to see
Will Ladislaw.  She did not know any good that could come of their
meeting: she was helpless; her hands had been tied from making up to
him for any unfairness in his lot.  But h

Probably some of Mr. Farebrother's Middlemarch hearers may follow him
to Lowick sometimes.  Do you not think so?

Perhaps Will Ladislaw,
having heard of that strange ban against him left by Mr. Casaubon, had
felt it better that he and she should not meet again, and perhaps she
was wrong to wish for a meeting that
I do wish it

Every leaf was at rest in the
sunshine, the familiar scene was changeless, and seemed to represent
the prospect of her life, full of motiveless ease—motiveless, if her
own energy could not seek out re
I will see him,

Let him be shown
into the drawing-room.

Presumed?  Surely not.  I should have thought it unkind if you had not
wished to see me,
And that will make it all the more honorable,

Besides, you have so many talents.  I have heard from my
uncle how well you speak in public, so that every one is sorry when you
leave off, and how clearly you can explain things.  And you care that
j

which
seemed to have in them the summers of all the years when Will would be

Yes, it must be right for you to do as you say.  I shall be very happy
when I hear that you have made your value felt.  But you must have
patience.  It will perhaps be a long while.
long while
No,

I shall never forget you.  I have never forgotten
any one whom I once knew.  My life has never been crowded, and seems
not likely to be so.  And I have a great deal of space for memory at
Lowick, have

If her uncle had been at home,
something might have been done through him!  It was this preoccupation
with the hardship of Will's wanting money, while she had what ought to
have been his share,

I wonder whether you would like to have that miniature which hangs
up-stairs—I mean that beautiful miniature of your grandmother.  I
think it is not right for me to keep it, if you would wish to have
I thought you would like to cherish her memory—I thought—
You are much the happier of us two, Mr. Ladislaw, to have nothing.

Sorrow comes in so many ways.  Two years ago I had no notion of
that—I mean of the unexpected way in which trouble comes, and ties our
hands, and makes us silent when we long to speak.  I used to desp
Ask Sir James to come in here,
How is Celia?

He was
going away into the distance of unknown years, and if ever he came back
he would be another man.  The actual state of his mind—his proud
resolve to give the lie beforehand to any suspicion that
I am so used to the cap—it has become a sort of shell,
I feel rather bare and exposed when it is off.
Not on my account, Sir James,

If you are speaking on my behalf, I can assure you
that no question can be more indifferent and impersonal to me than
second marriage.  It is no more to me than if you talked of women going
fox-huntin
Neither,

James spoke out of delicacy to me, but he
was mistaken in supposing that I minded what Mrs. Cadwallader said.  I
should only mind if there were a law obliging me to take any piece of
blood and beauty

Don't be anxious, Kitty; I have quite other thoughts about my life.  I
shall never marry again,

Not anybody at all.  I have
delightful plans.  I should like to take a great deal of land, and
drain it, and make a little colony, where everybody should work, and
all the work should be done well.  I

Advise me—think what I can
do—he has been all his life laboring and looking forward.  He minds
about nothing else—and I mind about nothing else.

You began by saying that one report was false, Mrs. Cadwallader, and I
believe this is false too,

at
least, I feel sure it is a misrepresentation.  I will not hear any evil
spoken of Mr. Ladislaw; he has already suffered too much injustice.
I am going on immediately to Tipton,
Good-by.
It is not true—it is not true!

He said he would never do anything that I disapproved—I wish I could
have told him that I disapproved of that,

They all try to blacken him before me; but
I will care for no pain, if he is not to blame.  I always believed he
was good.

I must stay here a little, Mrs. Kell.  I will go into the library and
write you some memoranda from my uncle's letter, if you will open the
shutters for me.
Go in first, and tell him that I am here.
Pray sit down,

I am
very glad you were here.

But the mixture of anger in her
agitation had vanished at the sight of him; she had been used, when
they were face to face, always to feel confidence and the happy freedom

I thought we had parted when you came to Lowick many weeks ago—you
thought you were going then,
You wished me to know the reasons?

It would be very unkind of you to suppose that I ever attributed any
meanness to you,

Do you suppose that I ever disbelieved in
you?
I am sure no safeguard was ever needed against you.

What

What shall you do in life?

Have your
intentions remained just the same as when we said good-by before?
Oh, what sad words!

We used to agree that we were alike
in speaking too strongly.

the

He wanted her to know that here too his conduct should be above

Presently,

I have
some memoranda to write for the housekeeper.
You have acted in every way rightly,
I have never done you injustice.  Please remember me,

Joy came first, in spite of the threatening train
behind it—joy in the impression that it was really herself whom Will

At

I was right to defend
him.

Driving was pleasant, for rain in the night had laid

place und

She could not look back at him. It was as if a
crowd of indifferent objects had thrust them asunder, and forced them

Need we part?

I only wish I had known before—I wish he knew—then we could be quite
happy in thinking of each other, though we are forever parted.  And if
I could but have given him the money, and made things easier

Celia.text:
Dodo is just the creature not to mind about having anything of her
own—children or anything!

And if she had had a baby, it never could have been such a dear as Arthur. Could it, James?

Not if it had been like Casaubon,
No! just imagine!  Really it was a mercy,

and I think it
is very nice for Dodo to be a widow.  She can be just as fond of our
baby as if it were her own, and she can have as many notions of her own
as she likes.
But what should we have been then?  We must have been something else,

I like
her better as she is.

What will you do at Lowick, Dodo?  You say yourself there is nothing
to be done there: everybody is so clean and well off, it makes you
quite melancholy.  And here you have been so happy going all abo
But you will never see him washed,

and that is quite the
best part of the day.

But this
was not until some episodes with baby were over, and had left her mind
at leisure.

Dear Dodo, do throw off that cap.  I am sure your dress must make you
feel ill.
I must see you without it; it makes us all warm,
It was I who did it, James,

Dodo need not make such a
slavery of her mourning; she need not wear that cap any more among her
friends.
Oh no,

Nobody chose the subject; it all came out of
Dodo's cap.  Mrs. Cadwallader only said what was quite true.  A woman
could not be married in a widow's cap, James.

Really, Dodo, taking your cap off made you like
yourself again in more ways than one.  You spoke up just as you used to
do, when anything was said to displease you.  But I could hardly make
out whethe

But you know, Dodo, if you ever did marry, it would be all the better
to have blood and beauty,
Really—quite?

Not anybody at all—if he were very
wonderful indeed?
Then you <emph rend="italics">will</emph> be happy, if you have a plan, Dodo?

Perhaps little Arthur will like plans when he grows up, and then he
can help you.

all
sorts of plans,

desirable that Dorothea should know there are reasons why she should
not receive him again; and I really can't say so to her.  It will come
lightly from you.

LC.text:
it was not
credible that Dorothea as a young widow would think of living alone in

personages, and in point of knowledge and senti

a widow must wear her mourning at
least a year.
That is very rare, I hope,

No friend of ours ever committed herself
in that way except Mrs. Beevor, and it was very painful to Lord
Grinsell when she did so.  Her first husband was objectionable, which
made it the greater wonde
My dear, your clever tongue runs away with you,

I am sure you would be the last woman to marry again prematurely, if
our dear Rector were taken away.

you
do not, I hope, think there was any allusion to you in my mentioning
Mrs. Beevor.  It was only an instance that occurred to me.  She was

MrsCad.text:
You will certainly go mad in that
house alone, my dear.  You will see visions.  We have all got to exert

other people call them by
But I suppose you have found out your mistake, my dear,
and that is a proof of sanity.

It will be well for her to marry again as soon

I have never entered on it,

Not if she marries again before the end of it,
Oh, if she took the wrong man!

Marriage is always bad then, first or second.
Priority is a poor recommendation in a husband if he has got no other.
I would rather have a good second husband than an indifferent first.

Oh, I make no vows; it might be a necessary economy.  It is lawful to

He is not gone, or going,

I hope I have not presumed too much in calling,

Very soon, I think.  I intend to go to town and eat my dinners as a

I shall never hear from you.  And you will forget all about me.
Good God!

It had seemed to him as if they were
like two creatures slowly turning to marble in each other's presence,
while their hearts were conscious and their eyes were yearning.  But
there was no help for it
You are very good,

No; I don't mind about it.
It is not very consoling to have one's own likeness.  It would be more
consoling if others wanted to have it.

you would surely like to have the miniature as a
family memorial.

Why should I have that, when I have nothing else!  A man with only a

it was a

I never felt it a misfortune to have nothing till now,

poverty may be as bad as leprosy, if it divides us from what we most

I have not given up doing as I like, but I can very seldom do it,

with conditions that would be intolerable.
I must say good-by, Mrs. Casaubon; and probably for a long while.

Yes, they are all true,

I have heard her say that she thought her mother did not know the

No,

I suppose you did know of my mother's existence, and knew where she

And was that business—or was it not—a thoroughly dishonorable

Yes, it is,

immediately, and I could not go without speaking to you again.

Yes; but I was in ignorance then of things which I know now—things

Yes,

I must go,
Yes,

I shall work away at the first thing that offers.  I

but still—it could not be fairly called wooing a woman to tell her

some miracle, clearly

F.text:
It was the harder to Fred's
disposition because his father, satisfied that he was no longer
rebellious, was in good humor with him, and had sent him on this
pleasant ride to see after some greyhounds.
What do you confounded fools mean?

I'll swear to every one of you before the
magistrate.  You've knocked the lad down and killed him, for what I
know.  You'll every one of you be hanged at the next assizes, if you
don't mind,

Wait a minute, and I'll come back presently, and have a round with you
all in turn, if you like,

Let them put the horse in the stable, and tell the surveyors they can
come back for their traps,
The ground is clear now.
I'm glad I happened to be here at the right moment, Mr. Garth,

No knowing what might have happened if the
cavalry had not come up in time.
Nothing, Mr. Garth.  I'll help you with pleasure—can I?

I don't mind anything.  Only I want to go first and have a round with
that hulky fellow who turned to challenge me.  It would be a good
lesson for him.  I shall not be five minutes.
I shall go with you, then,
I wish I had taken to it before I had thought of being a B. A.,

Do you
think I am too old to learn your business, Mr. Garth?
You do think I could do some good at it, if I were to try?
I can never feel that I should do that in being a clergyman,
That is very nearly what Mary thinks about it,

I think you must know what I feel for Mary, Mr. Garth: I hope it does
not displease you that I have always loved her better than any one
else, and that I shall never love any one as I love her.
I know that, Mr. Garth,

and I would do anything
for <emph rend="italics">her</emph>.  She says she will never have me if I go into the Church;
and I shall be the most miserable devil in the world if I lose all hope
of Mary.

Nothing, yet; but I must tell him.  I am only waiting to know what I
can do instead of entering the Church.  I am very sorry to disappoint
him, but a man ought to be allowed to judge for himself when

I asked Mr. Farebrother to talk to her, because she had forbidden
me—I didn't know what else to do,

And he
says that I have every reason to hope, if I can put myself in an
honorable position—I mean, out of the Church. I dare say you think it
unwarrantable in me, Mr. Garth, to be troubling you and ob

I'm not afraid of arithmetic, Mr. Garth: it always came easily to me.
I think you know my writing.
What can I do, Mr. Garth?

He did not like to disappoint himself there.

I am very sorry,

Moreover, the decision would be more certainly
understood to be final, if the interview took place in his father's

Yes, father.

I hope you will not object to my remaining at home, sir?

I shall have a sufficient salary to pay for my
board, as of course I should wish to do.

I hope you will shake hands with me, father, and forgive me the

he had begun to
see that this was a world in which even a spirited young man must

which made it the harder that he
should be held superior
How glad you must be to have Christy here!
He is a great fellow,
and no trouble to anybody.

But I fear you will think that I am going to be a great deal of

I know you think me very undeserving, Mrs. Garth, and with good

I happen to have behaved
just the worst to the people I can't help wishing for the most from.

I hope
it will not be so with me, Mrs. Garth, since I have some encouragement

You were not surprised, I dare say?

She never did give me any—not the least in the world, when I talked
to her myself,

But when I asked
Mr. Farebrother to speak for me, she allowed him to tell me there was a

Did I?

Mr. Farebrother has always been such a friend of ours; and Mary, I

I cannot conceive how it could be any pain to Mr. Farebrother,

Then you think I am standing in his way, and in Mary's too?

Mr. Garth seemed pleased that Mary should be attached to
me.  He could not have known anything of this.

have made a thoroughly good match.  Also he was piqued that

Mary had been staying at the parsonage
lately, and her mother might know very little of what had been passing
in her mind.

Miss Garth has such severe notions of what people should be that it is

was glad, of course, that Mr. Farebrother was so

It is impossible that you should not see it all clearly enough—you
who see everything.

If Mary had really
been unsuspicious, there was no good in telling her what Mrs. Garth had

It follows as a matter of course,

When you are
continually seeing a man who beats me in everything, and whom you set

No, I am not ungrateful; I should be the happiest fellow in the world

This dreadful certainty that I shall be bowled out by Farebrother.

I wish you would tell me that you could not possibly ever think of

MrV.text: So you've made up your mind at last, sir?

Very well; stick to it.  I've no more to say.  You've thrown away your
education, and gone down a step in life, when I had given you the means
of rising, that's all.

Very well; I have no more to say.  I wash my hands of you.  I only
hope, when you have a son of your own he will make a better return for
the pains you spend on him.

Of course
your mother will want you to stay.  But I shall keep no horse for you,
you understand; and you will pay your own tailor.  You will do with a
suit or two less, I fancy, when you have to pay f
Yes, yes, let us say no more.

Come, Lucy, my dear, don't be so down-hearted. You always have spoiled
the boy, and you must go on spoiling him.

Pooh, pooh, never mind!  We must expect to have trouble with our
children.  Don't make it worse by letting me see you out of spirits.
It won't do to begin making a fuss about one,

There's
Rosamond as well as Fred.

descriptions.D: 3> Negli occhi porta la mia donna Amore; Per che si fa gentil ciò ch'ella mira: Ov'ella passa, ogni uom ver lei si gira, E cui saluta fa tremar lo core. Sicchè, bassando il viso, tutto smore, E d'ogni suo difetto allor sospira: Fuggon dinanzi a lei Superbia ed Ira: Aiutatemi, donne, a farle onore. Ogni dolcezza, ogni pensiero umile Nasce nel core a chi parlar la sente; Ond'è beato chi prima la vide. Quel ch'ella par quand' un poco sorride, Non si può dicer, nè tener a mente, Si è nuovo miracolo
descriptions.Celia: est worthy of finest incense, Dorothea had again taken up her abode at Lowick Manor. After three months Freshitt had become rather oppressive: to sit like a model for Saint Catherine looking rapturously at Celia's baby would not do for many hours in the day, and to remain in that momentous babe's presence with persistent disregard was a course that could not have been tolerated in a childless sister. Dorothea would have been capable of carrying baby joyfully for a mile if there had been need, an
descriptions.B: rved table, and had rubbed elbows with Mr. Bambridge and Mr. Horrock. There was a wreath of Middlemarch ladies accommodated with seats round the large table in the dining-room, where Mr. Borthrop Trumbull was mounted with desk and hammer; but the rows chiefly of masculine faces behind were often varied by incomings and outgoings both from the door and the large bow-window opening on to the lawn. Everybody that day did not include Mr. Bulstrode, whose health could not well endure crowds and draug
descriptions.Lyd: sweetness tell. —SHAKESPEARE: Sonnets. At the time when Mr. Vincy uttered that presentiment about Rosamond, she herself had never had the idea that she should be driven to make the sort of appeal which he foresaw. She had not yet had any anxiety about ways and means, although her domestic life had been expensive as well as eventful. Her baby had been born prematurely, and all the embroidered robes and caps had to be laid by in darkness. This misfortune was attributed entirely to her having persi
descriptions.Lad: aw was below, and begged permission to see Madam if it were not too early. I will see him, said Dorothea, rising immediately. Let him be shown into the drawing-room. The drawing-room was the most neutral room in the house to her—the one least associated with the trials of her married life: the damask matched the wood-work, which was all white and gold; there were two tall mirrors and tables with nothing on them—in brief, it was a room where you had no reason for sitting in one place rather than
descriptions.R: e was a visit from Captain Lydgate, the baronet's third son, who, I am sorry to say, was detested by our Tertius of that name as a vapid fop parting his hair from brow to nape in a despicable fashion (not followed by Tertius himself), and showing an ignorant security that he knew the proper thing to say on every topic. Lydgate inwardly cursed his own folly that he had drawn down this visit by consenting to go to his uncle's on the wedding-tour, and he made himself rather disagreeable to Rosamond
descriptions.M: bout Mary. Mary had been staying at the parsonage lately, and her mother might know very little of what had been passing in her mind. He did not feel easier when he found her looking cheerful with the three ladies in the drawing-room. They were in animated discussion on some subject which was dropped when he entered, and Mary was copying the labels from a heap of shallow cabinet drawers, in a minute handwriting which she was skilled in. Mr. Farebrother was somewhere in the village, and the three
descriptions.F: s). He put up his gig at Yoddrell's, and in walking with his assistant and measuring-chain to the scene of his work, he encountered the party of the company's agents, who were adjusting their spirit-level. After a little chat he left them, observing that by-and-by they would reach him again where he was going to measure. It was one of those gray mornings after light rains, which become delicious about twelve o'clock, when the clouds part a little, and the scent of the earth is sweet along the la
descriptions.MB: niless. That was not what he could wish for even in his secret heart, or even if she had been ready to meet such hard contrast for his sake. And then, too, there was the fresh smart of that disclosure about his mother's family, which if known would be an added reason why Dorothea's friends should look down upon him as utterly below her. The secret hope that after some years he might come back with the sense that he had at least a personal value equal to her wealth, seemed now the dreamy continua
descriptions.JC: not do for many hours in the day, and to remain in that momentous babe's presence with persistent disregard was a course that could not have been tolerated in a childless sister. Dorothea would have been capable of carrying baby joyfully for a mile if there had been need, and of loving it the more tenderly for that labor; but to an aunt who does not recognize her infant nephew as Bouddha, and has nothing to do for him but to admire, his behavior is apt to appear monotonous, and the interest of w
descriptions.LC: ome and stay all night on purpose, said Dorothea; but I want to be alone now, and in my own home. I wish to know the Farebrothers better, and to talk to Mr. Farebrother about what there is to be done in Middlemarch. Dorothea's native strength of will was no longer all converted into resolute submission. She had a great yearning to be at Lowick, and was simply determined to go, not feeling bound to tell all her reasons. But every one around her disapproved. Sir James was much pained, and offered
descriptions.MrsV: ged! said Mr. Vincy, recovering himself in his disgust at the notion that Fred's keep would be missed at his table. Of course your mother will want you to stay. But I shall keep no horse for you, you understand; and you will pay your own tailor. You will do with a suit or two less, I fancy, when you have to pay for 'em. Fred lingered; there was still something to be said. At last it came. I hope you will shake hands with me, father, and forgive me the vexation I have caused you. Mr. Vincy from h
descriptions.MrV: would be more certainly understood to be final, if the interview took place in his father's gravest hours, which were always those spent in his private room at the warehouse. Fred entered on the subject directly, and declared briefly what he had done and was resolved to do, expressing at the end his regret that he should be the cause of disappointment to his father, and taking the blame on his own deficiencies. The regret was genuine, and inspired Fred with strong, simple words. Mr. Vincy listen
descriptions.MrsCad: a great yearning to be at Lowick, and was simply determined to go, not feeling bound to tell all her reasons. But every one around her disapproved. Sir James was much pained, and offered that they should all migrate to Cheltenham for a few months with the sacred ark, otherwise called a cradle: at that period a man could hardly know what to propose if Cheltenham were rejected. The Dowager Lady Chettam, just returned from a visit to her daughter in town, wished, at least, that Mrs. Vigo should be
